dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDon't debug with logs alone - check out \u003ca href=\"https://httptoolkit.tech/javascript\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHTTP Toolkit\u003c/a\u003e: beautiful, powerful \u0026amp; open-source tools for building, testing \u0026amp; debugging HTTP(S)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMinimal lightweight simple logging for JavaScript (browsers, node.js or elsewhere). loglevel extends \u003ccode\u003econsole.log()\u003c/code\u003e \u0026amp; friends with level-based logging and filtering, with none of console's downsides.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTest it out live in your browser console at \u003ca href=\"https://pimterry.github.io/loglevel/demo/index.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://pimterry.github.io/loglevel/demo/index.html\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLoglevel is a barebones reliable everyday logging library. It does not do fancy things, it does not let you reconfigure appenders or add complex log filtering rules or boil tea (more's the pity), but it does have the all core functionality that you actually use:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eFeatures\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca (trace/debug/info/warn/error) to the \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e object (as seen in all modern browsers \u0026amp; node.js).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFilter logging by level (all the above or 'silent'), so you can disable all but error logging in production, and then run \u003ccode\u003elog.setLevel(\"trace\")\u003c/code\u003e in your console to turn it all back on for a furious debugging session.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSingle file, no dependencies, weighs in at 1.4 KB minified and gzipped.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eEffective\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-effective\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Effective\" href=\"#effective\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLog methods gracefully fall back to simpler console logging methods if more specific ones aren't available: so calls to \u003ccode\u003elog.debug()\u003c/code\u003e go to \u003ccode\u003econsole.debug()\u003c/code\u003e if possible, or \u003ccode\u003econsole.log()\u003c/code\u003e if not.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLogging calls still succeed even if there's no \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e object at all, so your site doesn't break when people visit with old browsers that don't support the \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e object (here's looking at you, IE) and similar.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThis then comes together giving a consistent reliable API that works in every JavaScript environment with a console available, and never breaks anything anywhere else.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eConvenient\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-convenient\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Convenient\" href=\"#convenient\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLog output keeps line numbers: most JS logging frameworks call \u003ccode\u003econsole.log\u003c/code\u003e methods through wrapper functions, clobbering your stacktrace and making the extra info many browsers provide useless. We'll have none of that thanks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt works with all the standard JavaScript loading systems out of the box (CommonJS, AMD, or just as a global).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLogging is filtered to \"warn\" level by default, to keep your live site clean in normal usage (or you can trivially re-enable everything with an initial \u003ccode\u003elog.enableAll()\u003c/code\u003e call).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMagically handles situations where console logging is not initially available (IE8/9), and automatically enables logging as soon as it does become available (when developer console is opened).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTypeScript type definitions included, so no need for extra \u003ccode\u003e@types\u003c/code\u003e packages.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExtensible, to add other log redirection, filtering, or formatting functionality, while keeping all the above (except you will clobber your stacktrace, see \u003ca href=\"#plugins\"\u003e“Plugins”\u003c/a\u003e below).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 dir=\"auto\"\u003eloglevel is written as a UMD module, with a single object exported. Unfortunately, ES6 module loaders \u0026amp; transpilers don't all handle this the same way. Some will treat the object as the default export, while others use it as the root exported object. In addition, loglevel includes a \u003ccode\u003edefault\u003c/code\u003e property on the root object, designed to help handle this difference. Nonetheless, there are two possible syntaxes that might work for you:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor most tools, using the default import is the most convenient and flexible option:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import log from 'loglevel';\nlog.warn(\u0026quot;module-tastic\u0026quot;);\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'loglevel'\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e;\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003ewarn\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e(\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"module-tastic\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor some tools though, it might better to wildcard import the whole object:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import * as log from 'loglevel';\nlog.warn(\u0026quot;module-tastic\u0026quot;);\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eas\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e'loglevel'\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e;\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003ewarn\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e(\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"module-tastic\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere's no major difference, unless you're using TypeScript \u0026amp; building a loglevel plugin (in that case, see \u003ca class=\"issue-link js-issue-link\" data-error-text=\"Failed to load title\" data-id=\"674732494\" data-permission-text=\"Title is private\" data-url=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149/hovercard\" href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149\"\u003e#149\u003c/a\u003e). In general though, just use whichever suits your environment, and everything should work out fine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWith noConflict()\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-with-noconflict\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: With noConflict()\" href=\"#with-noconflict\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you're using another JavaScript library that exposes a \u003ccode\u003elog\u003c/code\u003e global, you can run into conflicts with loglevel. Similarly to jQuery, you can solve this by putting loglevel into no-conflict mode immediately after it is loaded onto the page. This resets the \u003ccode\u003elog\u003c/code\u003e global to its value before loglevel was loaded (typically \u003ccode\u003eundefined\u003c/code\u003e), and returns the loglevel object, which you can then bind to another name yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.trace(msg)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.debug(msg)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.info(msg)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.warn(msg)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.error(msg)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.log(msg)\u003c/code\u003e is also available, as an alias for \u003ccode\u003elog.debug(msg)\u003c/code\u003e, to improve compatibility with \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e, and make migration easier.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExact output formatting of these will depend on the console available in the current context of your application. For example, many environments will include a full stack trace with all \u003ccode\u003etrace()\u003c/code\u003e calls, and icons or similar to highlight other calls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThese methods should never fail in any environment, even if no \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e object is currently available, and should always fall back to an available log method even if the specific method called (e.g. \u003ccode\u003ewarn\u003c/code\u003e) isn't available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBe aware that this means that these methods won't always produce exactly the output you expect in every environment; loglevel only guarantees that these methods will never explode on you, and that it will call the most relevant method it can find, with your argument. For example, \u003ccode\u003elog.trace(msg)\u003c/code\u003e in Firefox before version 64 prints the stacktrace by itself, and doesn't include your message (see \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/84\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/issues/84/hovercard\"\u003e#84\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis disables all logging below the given level, so that after a \u003ccode\u003elog.setLevel(\"warn\")\u003c/code\u003e call \u003ccode\u003elog.warn(\"something\")\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003elog.error(\"something\")\u003c/code\u003e will output messages, but \u003ccode\u003elog.info(\"something\")\u003c/code\u003e will not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis can take either a log level name or \u003ccode\u003e'silent'\u003c/code\u003e (which disables everything) in one of a few forms:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs a log level from the internal levels list, e.g. \u003ccode\u003elog.levels.SILENT\u003c/code\u003e ← \u003cem\u003efor type safety\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs a string, like \u003ccode\u003e'error'\u003c/code\u003e (case-insensitive) ← \u003cem\u003efor a reasonable practical balance\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs a numeric index from \u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e (trace) to \u003ccode\u003e5\u003c/code\u003e (silent) ← \u003cem\u003edeliciously terse, and more easily programmable (...although, why?)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhere possible, the log level will be persisted. LocalStorage will be used if available, falling back to cookies if not. If neither is available in the current environment (e.g. in Node), or if you pass \u003ccode\u003efalse\u003c/code\u003e as the optional 'persist' second argument, persistence will be skipped.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf \u003ccode\u003elog.setLevel()\u003c/code\u003e is called when a \u003ccode\u003econsole\u003c/code\u003e object is not available (in IE 8 or 9 before the developer tools have been opened, for example) logging will remain silent until the console becomes available, and then begin logging at the requested level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003elog.setDefaultLevel(level)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-logsetdefaultlevellevel\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: log.setDefaultLevel(level)\" href=\"#logsetdefaultlevellevel\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis sets the current log level only if one has not been persisted and can’t be loaded. This is useful when initializing modules or scripts; if a developer or user has previously called \u003ccode\u003esetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e, this won’t alter their settings. For example, your application might use \u003ccode\u003esetDefaultLevel(\"error\")\u003c/code\u003e set the log level to \u003ccode\u003eerror\u003c/code\u003e in a production environment, but when debugging an issue, you might call \u003ccode\u003esetLevel(\"trace\")\u003c/code\u003e on the console to see all the logs. If that \u003ccode\u003eerror\u003c/code\u003e setting was set using \u003ccode\u003esetDefaultLevel()\u003c/code\u003e, it will still stay as \u003ccode\u003etrace\u003c/code\u003e on subsequent page loads and refreshes instead of resetting to \u003ccode\u003eerror\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003elevel\u003c/code\u003e argument takes the same values that you might pass to \u003ccode\u003esetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e. Levels set using \u003ccode\u003esetDefaultLevel()\u003c/code\u003e never persist to subsequent page loads.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis notably isn't the right solution to avoid the cost of string concatenation in your logging. Firstly, it's very unlikely that string concatenation in your logging is really an important performance problem. Even if you do genuinely have hard metrics showing that it is, though, the better solution that wrapping your log statements in this is to use multiple arguments, as below. The underlying console API will automatically concatenate these for you if logging is enabled, and if it isn't then all log methods are no-ops, and no concatenation will be done at all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"// Prints 'My concatenated log 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis gets you a new logger object that works exactly like the root \u003ccode\u003elog\u003c/code\u003e object, but can have its level and logging methods set independently. All loggers must have a name (which is a non-empty string, or a \u003ca href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Symbol\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSymbol\u003c/a\u003e). Calling \u003ccode\u003egetLogger()\u003c/code\u003e multiple times with the same name will return an identical logger object.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn large applications, it can be incredibly useful to turn logging on and off for particular modules as you are working with them. Using the \u003ccode\u003egetLogger()\u003c/code\u003e method lets you create a separate logger for each part of your application with its own logging level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLikewise, for small, independent modules, using a named logger instead of the default root logger allows developers using your module to selectively turn on deep, trace-level logging when trying to debug problems, while logging only errors or silencing logging altogether under normal circumstances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExample usage \u003cem\u003e(using CommonJS modules, but you could do the same with any module system):\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"// In module-one.js:\nvar log = require(\u0026quot;loglevel\u0026quot;).getLogger(\u0026quot;module-one\u0026quot;);\nfunction doSomethingAmazing() {\n  log.debug(\u0026quot;Amazing message from module one.\u0026quot;);\n}\n\n// In module-two.js:\nvar log = require(\u0026quot;loglevel\u0026quot;).getLogger(\u0026quot;module-two\u0026quot;);\nfunction doSomethingSpecial() {\n  log.debug(\u0026quot;Special message from module two.\u0026quot;);\n}\n\n// In your main application module:\nvar log = require(\u0026quot;loglevel\u0026quot;);\nvar moduleOne = require(\u0026quot;module-one\u0026quot;);\nvar moduleTwo = require(\u0026quot;module-two\u0026quot;);\nlog.getLogger(\u0026quot;module-two\u0026quot;).setLevel(\u0026quot;TRACE\u0026quot;);\n\nmoduleOne.doSomethingAmazing();\nmoduleTwo.doSomethingSpecial();\n// from module two.\"\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e// (but nothing from module one.)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLoggers returned by \u003ccode\u003egetLogger()\u003c/code\u003e support all the same properties and methods as the default root logger, excepting \u003ccode\u003enoConflict()\u003c/code\u003e and the \u003ccode\u003egetLogger()\u003c/code\u003e method itself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLike the root logger, other loggers can have their logging level saved. If a logger’s level has not been saved, it will inherit the root logger’s level when it is first created. If the root logger’s level changes later, the new level will not affect other loggers that have already been created. Loggers with Symbol names (rather than string names) will always be considered unique instances, and will never have their logging level saved or restored.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLikewise, loggers inherit the root logger’s \u003ccode\u003emethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e. After creation, each logger can have its \u003ccode\u003emethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e independently set. See the \u003cem\u003eplugins\u003c/em\u003e section below for more about \u003ccode\u003emethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 dir=\"auto\"\u003eEnsure the various logging methods (\u003ccode\u003elog.info()\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003elog.warn()\u003c/code\u003e, etc.) behave as expected given the currently set logging level and \u003ccode\u003emethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e. It will also rebuild all child loggers of the logger this was called on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis is mostly useful for plugin development. When you call \u003ccode\u003elog.setLevel()\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003elog.setDefaultLevel()\u003c/code\u003e, the logger is rebuilt automatically. However, if you change the logger’s \u003ccode\u003emethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e, you should use this to rebuild all the logging methods with your new factory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt is also useful if you change the level of the root logger and want it to affect child loggers that you’ve already created (and have not called \u003ccode\u003esomeChildLogger.setLevel()\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003esomeChildLogger.setDefaultLevel()\u003c/code\u003e on). For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"var childLogger1 = log.getLogger(\u0026quot;child1\u0026quot;);\nchildLogger1.getLevel();  // WARN (inherited from the root logger)\n\nvar childLogger2 = log.getLogger(\u0026quot;child2\u0026quot;);\nchildLogger2.setDefaultLevel(\u0026quot;TRACE\u0026quot;);\nchildLogger2.getLevel();  // TRACE\n\nlog.setLevel(\u0026quot;ERROR\u0026quot;);\n\n// At this point, the child loggers have not changed:\nchildLogger1.getLevel();  // WARN\nchildLogger2.getLevel();  // TRACE\n\n// To update them:\nlog.rebuild();\nchildLogger1.getLevel();  // ERROR (still inheriting from root logger)\nchildLogger2.getLevel();  // TRACE (no longer inheriting because `.setDefaultLevel() was called`)\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLoglevel provides a simple, reliable, minimal base for console logging that works everywhere. This means it doesn't include lots of fancy functionality that might be useful in some cases, such as log formatting and redirection (e.g. also sending log messages to a server over AJAX)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIncluding that would increase the size and complexity of the library, but more importantly would remove stacktrace information. Currently log methods are either disabled, or enabled with directly bound versions of the \u003ccode\u003econsole.log\u003c/code\u003e methods (where possible). This means your browser shows the log message as coming from your code at the call to \u003ccode\u003elog.info(\"message!\")\u003c/code\u003e not from within loglevel, since it really calls the bound console method directly, without indirection. The indirection required to dynamically format, further filter, or redirect log messages would stop this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere's clearly enough enthusiasm for this even at that cost that loglevel now includes a plugin API. To use it, redefine \u003ccode\u003elog.methodFactory(methodName, logLevel, loggerName)\u003c/code\u003e with a function of your own. This will be called for each enabled method each time the level is set (including initially), and should return a function to be used for the given log method \u003ccode\u003emethodName\u003c/code\u003e, at the given \u003cem\u003econfigured\u003c/em\u003e (not actual) level \u003ccode\u003elogLevel\u003c/code\u003e, for a logger with the given name \u003ccode\u003eloggerName\u003c/code\u003e. If you'd like to retain all the reliability and features of loglevel, we recommended that you wrap the initially provided value of \u003ccode\u003elog.methodFactory\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor example, a plugin to prefix all log messages with \"Newsflash: \" would look like:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"var originalFactory = log.methodFactory;\nlog.methodFactory = function (methodName, logLevel, loggerName) {\n    var rawMethod = originalFactory(methodName, logLevel, loggerName);\n\n    return function (message) {\n        rawMethod(\u0026quot;Newsflash: \u0026quot; + message);\n    };\n};\nlog.rebuild(); // Be sure to call the rebuild method in order to apply plugin.\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003evar\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eoriginalFactory\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003emethodFactory\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e;\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elog\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003emethodFactory\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efunction\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e(\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emethodName\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e,\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003elogLevel\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e,\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eloggerName\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-kos\"\u003e{\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003evar\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan supports only a single string \u003ccode\u003elog.warn(\"...\")\u003c/code\u003e argument for clarity, but it's easy to extend to a \u003ca href=\"http://jsbin.com/xehoye/edit?html,console\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efuller variadic version\u003c/a\u003e.)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you develop and release a plugin, please get in contact! I'd be happy to reference it here for future users. Some consistency is helpful; naming your plugin 'loglevel-PLUGINNAME' (e.g. loglevel-newsflash) is preferred, as is giving it the 'loglevel-plugin' keyword in your \u003ccode\u003epackage.json\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eDeveloping \u0026amp; Contributing\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-developing--contributing\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Developing \u0026amp; Contributing\" href=\"#developing--contributing\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn lieu of a formal styleguide, take care to maintain the existing coding style. Add unit tests for any new or changed functionality.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBuilds can be run with npm: run \u003ccode\u003enpm run dist\u003c/code\u003e to build a distributable version of the project (in \u003ccode\u003edist/\u003c/code\u003e), or \u003ccode\u003enpm test\u003c/code\u003e to just run the tests and linting. During development you can run \u003ccode\u003enpm run watch\u003c/code\u003e and it will monitor source files, and rerun the tests and linting as appropriate when they're changed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlso, please don't manually edit files in the \u003ccode\u003edist/\u003c/code\u003e subdirectory as they are generated via Grunt. tested\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.2.0 - Updated release with various tweaks and polish and real proper documentation attached\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.3.0 - Some bugfixes (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/12\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/12/hovercard\"\u003e#12\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/14\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/issues/14/hovercard\"\u003e#14\u003c/a\u003e), cookie-based log level persistence, doc tweaks, support for Bower and JamJS\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.3.1 - Fixed incorrect text in release build banner, various other minor tweaks\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.4.0 - Use LocalStorage for level persistence if available, compatibility improvements for IE, improved error messages, multi-environment tests\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.5.0 - Fix for Modernizr+IE8 issues, improved setLevel error handling, support for auto-activation of desired logging when console eventually turns up in IE8\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev0.6.0 - Handle logging in Safari private browsing mode (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/33\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/33/hovercard\"\u003e#33\u003c/a\u003e), fix \u003ccode\u003eTRACE\u003c/code\u003e level persistence bug (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/35\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/35/hovercard\"\u003e#35\u003c/a\u003e), plus various minor tweaks\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.0.0 - Official stable release! Fixed a bug with localStorage in Android webviews, improved CommonJS detection, and added \u003ccode\u003enoConflict()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.1.0 - Added support for including loglevel with preprocessing and \u003ccode\u003e.apply()\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/50\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/50/hovercard\"\u003e#50\u003c/a\u003e), and fixed QUnit dep version which made tests potentially unstable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.2.0 - New plugin API! Plus various bits of refactoring and tidy up, nicely simplifying things and trimming the size down.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.3.0 - Make persistence optional in \u003ccode\u003esetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e, plus lots of documentation updates and other small tweaks\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.3.1 - With the new optional persistence, stop unnecessarily persisting the initially set default level (\u003ccode\u003eWARN\u003c/code\u003e)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.4.0 - Add \u003ccode\u003egetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003esetDefaultLevel()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003egetLogger()\u003c/code\u003e functionality for more fine-grained log level control\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.4.1 - Reorder UMD (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/92\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/92/hovercard\"\u003e#92\u003c/a\u003e) to improve bundling tool compatibility\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.5.0 - Fix \u003ccode\u003elog.debug\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/111\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/issues/111/hovercard\"\u003e#111\u003c/a\u003e) after V8 changes deprecating console.debug, check for \u003ccode\u003ewindow\u003c/code\u003e upfront (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/104\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/104/hovercard\"\u003e#104\u003c/a\u003e), and add \u003ccode\u003e.log\u003c/code\u003e alias for \u003ccode\u003e.debug\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/64\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/issues/64/hovercard\"\u003e#64\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.5.1 - Fix bug (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/112\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/112/hovercard\"\u003e#112\u003c/a\u003e) in level-persistence cookie fallback, which failed if it wasn't the first cookie present\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.0 - Add a name property to loggers and add \u003ccode\u003elog.getLoggers()\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/114\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/pimterry/loglevel/pull/114/hovercard\"\u003e#114\u003c/a\u003e), and recommend unpkg as CDN instead of CDNJS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.1 - Various small documentation \u0026amp; test updates\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.2 - Include TypeScript type definitions in the package itself\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.3 - Avoid TypeScript type conflicts with other global \u003ccode\u003elog\u003c/code\u003e types (e.g. \u003ccode\u003ecore-js\u003c/code\u003e)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.4 - Ensure \u003ccode\u003epackage.json\u003c/code\u003e's \u003ccode\u003e\"main\"\u003c/code\u003e is a fully qualified path, to fix webpack issues\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.5 - Ensure the provided message is included when calling \u003ccode\u003etrace()\u003c/code\u003e in IE11\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.6 - Fix bugs in v1.6.5, which caused issues in node.js \u0026amp; IE \u0026lt; 9\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.7 - Fix a bug in environments with \u003ccode\u003ewindow\u003c/code\u003e defined but no \u003ccode\u003ewindow.navigator\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.6.8 - Update TypeScript type definitions to include \u003ccode\u003elog.log()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.7.0 - Add support for Symbol-named loggers, and a \u003ccode\u003e.default\u003c/code\u003e property to help with ES6 module usage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.7.1 - Update TypeScript types to support Symbol-named loggers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.8.0 - Add \u003ccode\u003eresetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e method to clear persisted levels \u0026amp; reset to defaults\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.8.1 - Fix incorrect type definitions for \u003ccode\u003eMethodFactory\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.9.0 - Added \u003ccode\u003erebuild()\u003c/code\u003e method, overhaul dev \u0026amp; test setup, and fix some bugs (notably around cookies) en route\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.9.1 - Fix a bug introduced in 1.9.0 that broke \u003ccode\u003esetLevel()\u003c/code\u003e in some ESM-focused runtime environments\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eloglevel\u003c/code\u003e for enterprise\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-loglevel-for-enterprise\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: loglevel for enterprise\" href=\"#loglevel-for-enterprise\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAvailable as part of the Tidelift Subscription.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe maintainers of \u003ccode\u003eloglevel\u003c/code\u003e and thousands of other packages are working with Tidelift to deliver commercial support and maintenance for the open source dependencies you use to build your applications. out <a href="https://httptoolkit.tech/javascript" rel="nofollow">HTTP Toolkit</a>: beautiful, powerful & open-source tools for building, testing & debugging HTTP(S)</em></p></blockquote><p dir="auto">Minimal lightweight simple logging for JavaScript (browsers, node.js or elsewhere). loglevel extends <code>console.log()</code> & friends with level-based logging and filtering, with none of console's downsides.</p><p dir="auto">Test it out live in your browser console at <a href="https://pimterry.github.io/loglevel/demo/index.html" rel="nofollow">https://pimterry.github.io/loglevel/demo/index.html</a></p><p dir="auto">Loglevel is a barebones reliable everyday logging library. It does not do fancy things, it does not let you reconfigure appenders or add complex log filtering rules or boil tea (more's the pity), but it does have the all core functionality that you actually use:</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Features</h2><a id="user-content-features" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Features" href="#features"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 dir="auto">Simple</h3><a id="user-content-simple" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Simple" href="#simple"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>Log things at a given level (trace/debug/info/warn/error) to the <code>console</code> object (as seen in all modern browsers & node.js).</li><li>Filter logging by level (all the above or 'silent'), so you can disable all but error logging in production, and then run <code>log.setLevel("trace")</code> in your console to turn it all back on for a furious debugging session.</li><li>Single file, no dependencies, weighs in at 1.4 KB minified and gzipped.</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Effective</h3><a id="user-content-effective" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Effective" href="#effective"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>Log methods gracefully fall back to simpler console logging methods if more specific ones aren't available: so calls to <code>log.debug()</code> go to <code>console.debug()</code> if possible, or <code>console.log()</code> if not.</li><li>Logging calls still succeed even if there's no <code>console</code> object at all, so your site doesn't break when people visit with old browsers that don't support the <code>console</code> object (here's looking at you, IE) and similar.</li><li>This then comes together giving a consistent reliable API that works in every JavaScript environment with a console available, and never breaks anything anywhere else.</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Convenient</h3><a id="user-content-convenient" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Convenient" href="#convenient"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>Log output keeps line numbers: most JS logging frameworks call <code>console.log</code> methods through wrapper functions, clobbering your stacktrace and making the extra info many browsers provide useless. We'll have none of that thanks.</li><li>It works with all the standard JavaScript loading systems out of the box (CommonJS, AMD, or just as a global).</li><li>Logging is filtered to "warn" level by default, to keep your live site clean in normal usage (or you can trivially re-enable everything with an initial <code>log.enableAll()</code> call).</li><li>Magically handles situations where console logging is not initially available (IE8/9), and automatically enables logging as soon as it does become available (when developer console is opened).</li><li>TypeScript type definitions included, so no need for extra <code>@types</code> packages.</li><li>Extensible, to add other log redirection, filtering, or formatting functionality, while keeping all the above (except you will clobber your stacktrace, see <a href="#plugins">“Plugins”</a> below).</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Downloading loglevel</h2><a id="user-content-downloading-loglevel" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Downloading loglevel" href="#downloading-loglevel"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If you're using NPM, you can just run <code>npm install loglevel</code>.</p><p dir="auto">Alternatively, loglevel is also available via <a href="https://github.com/bower/bower">Bower</a> (<code>bower install loglevel</code>), as a <a href="http://www.webjars.org/" rel="nofollow">Webjar</a>, or an <a href="https://atmospherejs.com/spacejamio/loglevel" rel="nofollow">Atmosphere package</a> (for Meteor)</p><p dir="auto">Alternatively if you just want to grab the file yourself, you can download either the current stable <a href="https://raw.github.com/pimterry/loglevel/master/dist/loglevel.min.js">production version</a> or the <a href="https://raw.github.com/pimterry/loglevel/master/dist/loglevel.js">development version</a> directly, or reference it remotely on unpkg at <a href="https://unpkg.com/loglevel/dist/loglevel.min.js" rel="nofollow"><code>https://unpkg.com/loglevel/dist/loglevel.min.js</code></a> (this will redirect to a latest version, use the resulting redirected URL if you want to pin that version).</p><p dir="auto">Finally, if you want to tweak loglevel to your own needs or you immediately need the cutting-edge version, clone this repo and see <a href="#developing--contributing">Developing & Contributing</a> below for build instructions.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Setting it up</h2><a id="user-content-setting-it-up" class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">As an ES6 module</h3><a id="user-content-as-an-es6-module" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: As an ES6 module" href="#as-an-es6-module"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">loglevel is written as a UMD module, with a single object exported. Unfortunately, ES6 module loaders & transpilers don't all handle this the same way. Some will treat the object as the default export, while others use it as the root exported object. In addition, loglevel includes a <code>default</code> property on the root object, designed to help handle this difference. Nonetheless, there are two possible syntaxes that might work for you:</p><p dir="auto">For most tools, using the default import is the most convenient and flexible option:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import log from 'loglevel';log.warn("module-tastic");"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">'loglevel'</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">warn</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"module-tastic"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">For some tools though, it might better to wildcard import the whole object:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import * as log from 'loglevel';log.warn("module-tastic");"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-c1">*</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">'loglevel'</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">warn</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"module-tastic"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">There's no major difference, unless you're using TypeScript & building a loglevel plugin (in that case, see <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="674732494" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149/hovercard" href="https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/149">#149</a>). In general though, just use whichever suits your environment, and everything should work out fine.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">With noConflict()</h3><a id="user-content-with-noconflict" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: With noConflict()" href="#with-noconflict"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If you're using another JavaScript library that exposes a <code>log</code> global, you can run into conflicts with loglevel. Similarly to jQuery, you can solve this by putting loglevel into no-conflict mode immediately after it is loaded onto the page. This resets the <code>log</code> global to its value before loglevel was loaded (typically <code>undefined</code>), and returns the loglevel object, which you can then bind to another name yourself.</p><p dir="auto">For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="<script src="loglevel.min.js"></script><script>var logging = log.noConflict();logging.warn("still pretty easy");</script>"><pre><span class="pl-kos"><</span><span class="pl-ent">script</span> <span class="pl-c1">src</span>="<span class="pl-s">loglevel.min.js</span>"<span class="pl-kos">></span><span class="pl-kos"></</span><span class="pl-ent">script</span><span class="pl-kos">></span><span class="pl-kos"><</span><span class="pl-ent">script</span><span class="pl-kos">></span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">logging</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">noConflict</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">logging</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">warn</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"still pretty easy"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-kos"></</span><span class="pl-ent">script</span><span class="pl-kos">></span></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">TypeScript</h3><a id="user-content-typescript" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: TypeScript" href="#typescript"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">loglevel includes its own type definitions, assuming you're using a modern module environment (e.g. Node.JS, webpack, etc), you should be able to use the ES6 syntax above, and everything will work immediately. If not, file a bug!</p><p dir="auto">If you really want to use LogLevel as a global however, but from TypeScript, you'll need to declare it as such first. To do that:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Create a <code>loglevel.d.ts</code> file</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Ensure that file is included in your build (e.g. add it to <code>include</code> in your tsconfig, pass it on the command line, or use <code>///<reference path="./loglevel.d.ts" /></code>)</p></li><li><p dir="auto">In that file, add:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-ts notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import * as log from 'loglevel';export as namespace log;export = log;"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-c1">*</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">'loglevel'</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-k">namespace</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div></li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Methods" href="#methods"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The loglevel API is extremely minimal. All methods are available on the root loglevel object, which we suggest you name <code>log</code> (this is the default if you import it globally, and is what's set up in the above examples). The API consists of:</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Logging Methods</h4><a id="user-content-logging-methods" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Logging Methods" href="#logging-methods"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">5 actual logging methods, ordered and available as:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>log.trace(msg)</code></li><li><code>log.debug(msg)</code></li><li><code>log.info(msg)</code></li><li><code>log.warn(msg)</code></li><li><code>log.error(msg)</code></li></ul><p dir="auto"><code>log.log(msg)</code> is also available, as an alias for <code>log.debug(msg)</code>, to improve compatibility with <code>console</code>, and make migration easier.</p><p dir="auto">Exact output formatting of these will depend on the console available in the current context of your application. For example, many environments will include a full stack trace with all <code>trace()</code> calls, and icons or similar to highlight other calls.</p><p dir="auto">These methods should never fail in any environment, even if no <code>console</code> object is currently available, and should always fall back to an available log method even if the specific method called (e.g. <code>warn</code>) isn't available.</p><p dir="auto">Be aware that this means that these methods won't always produce exactly the output you expect in every environment; loglevel only guarantees that these methods will never explode on you, and that it will call the most relevant method it can find, with your argument. For example, <code>log.trace(msg)</code> in Firefox before version 64 prints the stacktrace by itself, and doesn't include your message (see <a href="https://github.com/pimterry/loglevel/issues/84" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/pimterry/loglevel/issues/84/hovercard">#84</a>).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.setLevel(level, [persist])</code></h4><a id="user-content-logsetlevellevel-persist" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.setLevel(level, [persist])" href="#logsetlevellevel-persist"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">This disables all logging below the given level, so that after a <code>log.setLevel("warn")</code> call <code>log.warn("something")</code> or <code>log.error("something")</code> will output messages, but <code>log.info("something")</code> will not.</p><p dir="auto">This can take either a log level name or <code>'silent'</code> (which disables everything) in one of a few forms:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>As a log level from the internal levels list, e.g. <code>log.levels.SILENT</code> ← <em>for type safety</em></li><li>As a string, like <code>'error'</code> (case-insensitive) ← <em>for a reasonable practical balance</em></li><li>As a numeric index from <code>0</code> (trace) to <code>5</code> (silent) ← <em>deliciously terse, and more easily programmable (...although, why?)</em></li></ul><p dir="auto">Where possible, the log level will be persisted. LocalStorage will be used if available, falling back to cookies if not. If neither is available in the current environment (e.g. in Node), or if you pass <code>false</code> as the optional 'persist' second argument, persistence will be skipped.</p><p dir="auto">If <code>log.setLevel()</code> is called when a <code>console</code> object is not available (in IE 8 or 9 before the developer tools have been opened, for example) logging will remain silent until the console becomes available, and then begin logging at the requested level.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.setDefaultLevel(level)</code></h4><a id="user-content-logsetdefaultlevellevel" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.setDefaultLevel(level)" href="#logsetdefaultlevellevel"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">This sets the current log level only if one has not been persisted and can’t be loaded. This is useful when initializing modules or scripts; if a developer or user has previously called <code>setLevel()</code>, this won’t alter their settings. For example, your application might use <code>setDefaultLevel("error")</code> set the log level to <code>error</code> in a production environment, but when debugging an issue, you might call <code>setLevel("trace")</code> on the console to see all the logs. If that <code>error</code> setting was set using <code>setDefaultLevel()</code>, it will still stay as <code>trace</code> on subsequent page loads and refreshes instead of resetting to <code>error</code>.</p><p dir="auto">The <code>level</code> argument takes the same values that you might pass to <code>setLevel()</code>. Levels set using <code>setDefaultLevel()</code> never persist to subsequent page loads.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.resetLevel()</code></h4><a id="user-content-logresetlevel" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.resetLevel()" href="#logresetlevel"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">This resets the current log level to the logger's default level (if no explicit default was set, then it resets it to the root logger's level, or to <code>WARN</code>) and clears the persisted level if one was previously persisted.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.enableAll()</code> and <code>log.disableAll()</code></h4><a id="user-content-logenableall-and-logdisableall" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.enableAll() and log.disableAll()" href="#logenableall-and-logdisableall"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 equivalent to <code>log.setLevel("trace")</code> and <code>log.setLevel("silent")</code>, respectively.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.getLevel()</code></h4><a id="user-content-loggetlevel" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.getLevel()" href="#loggetlevel"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Returns the current logging level, as a number from <code>0</code> (trace) to <code>5</code> (silent)</p><p dir="auto">It's very unlikely you'll need to use this for normal application logging; it's provided partly to help plugin development, and partly to let you optimize logging code as below, where debug data is only generated if the level is set such that it'll actually be logged. This probably doesn't affect you, unless you've run profiling on your code and you have hard numbers telling you that your log data generation is a real performance problem.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="if (log.getLevel() <= log.levels.DEBUG) {  var logData = runExpensiveDataGeneration();  log.debug(logData);}"><pre><span class="pl-k">if</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">getLevel</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c1"><=</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">levels</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">DEBUG</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">logData</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">runExpensiveDataGeneration</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>  <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">debug</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">logData</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">This notably isn't the right solution to avoid the cost of string concatenation in your logging. Firstly, it's very unlikely that string concatenation in your logging is really an important performance problem. Even if you do genuinely have hard metrics showing that it is, though, the better solution that wrapping your log statements in this is to use multiple arguments, as below. The underlying console API will automatically concatenate these for you if logging is enabled, and if it isn't then all log methods are no-ops, and no concatenation will be done at all.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// Prints 'My concatenated log message'log.debug("My", "concatenated", "log message");"><pre><span class="pl-c">// Prints 'My concatenated log message'</span><span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">debug</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"My"</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">"concatenated"</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">"log message"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.getLogger(loggerName)</code></h4><a id="user-content-loggetloggerloggername" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.getLogger(loggerName)" href="#loggetloggerloggername"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">This gets you a new logger object that works exactly like the root <code>log</code> object, but can have its level and logging methods set independently. All loggers must have a name (which is a non-empty string, or a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Symbol" rel="nofollow">Symbol</a>). Calling <code>getLogger()</code> multiple times with the same name will return an identical logger object.</p><p dir="auto">In large applications, it can be incredibly useful to turn logging on and off for particular modules as you are working with them. Using the <code>getLogger()</code> method lets you create a separate logger for each part of your application with its own logging level.</p><p dir="auto">Likewise, for small, independent modules, using a named logger instead of the default root logger allows developers using your module to selectively turn on deep, trace-level logging when trying to debug problems, while logging only errors or silencing logging altogether under normal circumstances.</p><p dir="auto">Example usage <em>(using CommonJS modules, but you could do the same with any module system):</em></p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// In module-one.js:var log = require("loglevel").getLogger("module-one");function doSomethingAmazing() {  log.debug("Amazing message from module one.");}// In module-two.js:var log = require("loglevel").getLogger("module-two");function doSomethingSpecial() {  log.debug("Special message from module two.");}// In your main application module:var log = require("loglevel");var moduleOne = require("module-one");var moduleTwo = require("module-two");log.getLogger("module-two").setLevel("TRACE");moduleOne.doSomethingAmazing();moduleTwo.doSomethingSpecial();// logs "Special message from module two."// (but nothing from module one.)"><pre><span class="pl-c">// In module-one.js:</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">require</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"loglevel"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">getLogger</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"Amazing message from module one."</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-c">// In module-two.js:</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">require</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"module-one"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">moduleTwo</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">getLogger</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"module-two"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">setLevel</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"TRACE"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">moduleOne</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">doSomethingAmazing</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">moduleTwo</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">doSomethingSpecial</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-c">// logs "Special message from module two."</span><span class="pl-c">// (but nothing from module one.)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">Loggers returned by <code>getLogger()</code> support all the same properties and methods as the default root logger, excepting <code>noConflict()</code> and the <code>getLogger()</code> method itself.</p><p dir="auto">Like the root logger, other loggers can have their logging level saved. If a logger’s level has not been saved, it will inherit the root logger’s level when it is first created. If the root logger’s level changes later, the new level will not affect other loggers that have already been created. Loggers with Symbol names (rather than string names) will always be considered unique instances, and will never have their logging level saved or restored.</p><p dir="auto">Likewise, loggers inherit the root logger’s <code>methodFactory</code>. After creation, each logger can have its <code>methodFactory</code> independently set. See the <em>plugins</em> section below for more about <code>methodFactory</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>log.getLoggers()</code></h4><a id="user-content-loggetloggers" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: log.getLoggers()" href="#loggetloggers"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" etc.) behave as expected given the currently set logging level and <code>methodFactory</code>. It will also rebuild all child loggers of the logger this was called on.</p><p dir="auto">This is mostly useful for plugin development. When you call <code>log.setLevel()</code> or <code>log.setDefaultLevel()</code>, the logger is rebuilt automatically. However, if you change the logger’s <code>methodFactory</code>, you should use this to rebuild all the logging methods with your new factory.</p><p dir="auto">It is also useful if you change the level of the root logger and want it to affect child loggers that you’ve already created (and have not called <code>someChildLogger.setLevel()</code> or <code>someChildLogger.setDefaultLevel()</code> on). For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var childLogger1 = height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Loglevel provides a simple, reliable, minimal base for console logging that works everywhere. This means it doesn't include lots of fancy functionality that might be useful in some cases, such as log formatting and redirection (e.g. also sending log messages to a server over AJAX)</p><p dir="auto">Including that would increase the size and complexity of the library, but more importantly would remove stacktrace information. Currently log methods are either disabled, or enabled with directly bound versions of the <code>console.log</code> methods (where possible). This means your browser shows the log message as coming from your code at the call to <code>log.info("message!")</code> not from within loglevel, since it really calls the bound console method directly, without indirection. The indirection required to dynamically format, further filter, or redirect log messages would stop this.</p><p dir="auto">There's clearly enough enthusiasm for this even at that cost that loglevel now includes a plugin API. To use it, redefine <code>log.methodFactory(methodName, logLevel, loggerName)</code> with a function of your own. This will be called for each enabled method each time the level is set (including initially), and should return a function to be used for the given log method <code>methodName</code>, at the given <em>configured</em> (not actual) level <code>logLevel</code>, for a logger with the given name <code>loggerName</code>. If you'd like to retain all the reliability and features of loglevel, we recommended that you wrap the initially provided value of <code>log.methodFactory</code>.</p><p dir="auto">For example, a plugin to prefix all log messages with "Newsflash: " would look like:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var originalFactory = log.methodFactory;log.methodFactory = function (methodName, logLevel, loggerName) {    var rawMethod = originalFactory(methodName, logLevel, loggerName);    return function (message) {        rawMethod("Newsflash: " + message);    };};log.rebuild(); // Be sure to call the rebuild method in order to apply plugin."><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">originalFactory</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">methodFactory</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span><span class="pl-s1">log</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">methodFactory</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">methodName</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">logLevel</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">loggerName</span><span dir="auto">If you develop and release a plugin, please get in contact! I'd be happy to reference it here for future users. Some consistency is helpful; naming your plugin 'loglevel-PLUGINNAME' (e.g. loglevel-newsflash) is preferred, as is giving it the 'loglevel-plugin' keyword in your <code>package.json</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Developing & Contributing</h2><a id="user-content-developing--contributing" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Developing & Contributing" href="#developing--contributing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In lieu of a formal styleguide, take care to maintain the existing coding style. Add unit tests for any new or changed functionality.</p><p dir="auto">Builds can be run with npm: run <code>npm run dist</code> to build a distributable version of the project (in <code>dist/</code>), or <code>npm test</code> to just run the tests and linting. During development you can run <code>npm run watch</code> and it will monitor source files, and rerun the tests and linting as appropriate when they're changed.</p><p dir="auto"><em>Also, please don't manually edit files in the <code>dist/</code> subdirectory as they are generated via Grunt. You'll find source code in the <code>lib/</code> subdirectory!</em></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Release process</h4><a id="user-content-release-process" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Release process" href="#release-process"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16"
